content.description: A fun climb up blocky edges with a bunch of footwork options, including backstepping moves to a dihedral to the left of the route.
content.protection: Well protected with 5 bolts to two Metolious rap hangers.
content.location: The route is to the right of a dihedral/broken crack system. The climb is on the first line of bolts from the right of 'Welcome to Black Rocks' 5.10a.

content.description: Climb up somewhat dirty and blocky rock to reach a  stance at the overhanging crack bulge.  The crux is getting from bolt 1 to 2 using the crack and a shallow pocket.  From here, its pretty cruiser, but very fun face climbing with positive holds throughout.
content.location: West of The Beginning by about 20 yards.  Locate a clean face with a crack system about 15 feet up.  For reference, there's another bolted climb about 15 feet to the left that ascends a smooth bulge on small edges.

content.description: Great route, starts right below the anchor to 5 am lookouts. Some ez climbing to a little roof problem to some vertical techy climbing. Good route.
content.protection: A couple finger size pieces and i also found places for a # 1, 2 and three. If you brought a singles rack from a .3- #3 you should find plenty of placements. Also bring four draws. Two for the upper section and then two for the anchors.
content.location: The line is right below the 5 am lookouts anchor.

content.description:
A good welcome to black rocks indeed, this route is a nice way to get started and a nice intro to whats in store for you while visiting. One of the easier routes at the grade,

Welcome to Black Rocks

won't blow a finger or your confidence.

A low crux with a mellow finish makes this the feel good route of the wall. A difficult start through a bulge and big blocky edges gets things moving. Steepening climbing with a few well placed, but shallow edges help maintain the flow.
content.protection: Six bolts and a rap anchor.
content.location:
Welcome to Black Rocks

sit more towards the west end of

The Shady Side

between

What Was I Thinking

and

The 5am Lookout

.

content.description: Start on Neutrino Drizzle, then break right at the second bolt following the seam toward the arete.
content.protection: 4 bolts, two hangers at the anchor
content.location: obvious right trending bolt line that starts with Neutrino Drizzle

content.description: Climb the nice hand-jam crack up to the dihedral.  From here, climb the right crack that turns into a skinny offwidth at the top (if you go left it looks as though you're climbing a finger crack).  Shady wall is great for when it gets hot in St. George.
content.protection: Assuming standard rack, but unsure since I topropped it.
content.location: Just to the right of Extinction (5.10a) and left of Polluting the Gene Pool (5.11a).

content.description: Shares the first two bolts of 5am Lookouts then veers rightward.

Start by laybacking to reach out left to reach the beginning of the arete. Crux is gaining the 3rd bolt.  Very balancy.  Blowing the moves to reach the 3rd bolt could result in a crappy awkward fall.  Nice bouldery moves at the beginning lead to fun face climbing.   This route is easily top roped by climbing Flirting with the Mutants, 5.11b to the right.
content.location: Locate the obvious arete about 20 feet to the right of Flying off the Handle, 5.12b.

content.description: I'm not sure why I'm adding this route.  It's really not worth doing.  Maybe to help you find other routes at Black Rocks?  Either way; this climb starts by climbing an easy and big block (6ft tall from ground?).  Belay from below or on top of the big rock to first bolt.  Then proceed to climb the small face to another ledge.  Simply stand to clip anchors.
content.location: To the left of Indifference (5.9).  Look above a 6ft tall block for the first bolt.

content.description: Starts on an overhang with a harder vertical section above.
content.location: Just left of Welcome to Black Rocks

content.description: This is a really weird line that starts on the right face of an inside corner that tops out on a ledge.  Once you're finished resting on the ledge (it is such a long climb) proceed to the crux bulge that ends at the anchor ledge.  The real crux is routefinding, rather, figuring out why this was bolted in the first place.  Nevertheless, this makes for a decent warm-up, and is fun for the family to top-rope.
content.location: Shady side of the canyon, one of the first routes you encounter from the trail.  Starts on the right face of a corner.  You can walk off the top or rappel off of the anchors.

content.description:
Awkward, odd, and wandering climbing on the right side of a blunt arete leads to steeper, trickier terrain. While the crux of this route may be considered down low, the true crux may be clipping the anchor.

Hair raising !
content.protection: Four bolts and a rap rings.
content.location:
The third route from the right when entering

Black Rock's Shady Side

. This sits directly left of

Run Bunny Run

content.description:
This route ascends the right facing dihedral to the right of "Event Horizon."  The crux is getting to the first placement.  As you climb this you will find that there are great stances every time that you feel that you need to place gear. It's great!

(There was chalk all over this crack so if you know who climbed it first or the original name please let me know and I'll make the appropriate changes.)
content.protection:
Camalots up to #1

Use anchor bolts on either side of the dihedral.
content.location:
Right of "Event Horizon"

Rap off chains or rap hangers.

content.description:
Having actually seen neutrino drizzle, i can say it looks nothing like this route.

Short and fun, this line isn't too hard to figure out. Fairly straight foward,

Neutrino Drizzle

is good pulling on good rock! A mid-route crux gives this route a nice flow.  Give it a hurl~!
content.location:
This route is on the far west end of the

Shady Side

and just right of a prominent corner. Its currently the second to last route on the wall.

content.description: Tricky crimpy pocket holds up a face to a ledge roughly about 20-25ft up, then finish the route on another small face above (10 more feet).
content.location: Two routes to the right of Run Bunny Run (5.9+).  If you see bolts on a route that is slightly overhanging with small crimps for holds (Hippy's Wrath - 5.11c), this route is directly to the right of it.

content.description: I entered this route to see if anyone knows what it is.   It's not in the Goss book, but looks interesting.  Low angle start with large moves between positive holds.  Pull small roof on left and up pocketed and featured face.
content.location: Located between Ginsu and Mission Impossible.

content.description: Thin low angle climb.  Quite techy with interesting sequences throughout.
content.location: 2 routes to the right of Ginsu.

content.description: Long and sustained for the area, Jumping to Conclusions offers-up a good variety fun moves and testing top out. I vote: Dyno off the crips.
content.location:
Shares start with

Flying Off the Handle

; break left to finish.

content.description: Really easy climbing leads to a generous rest ledge.  This is trad climbing for people on a 6 quickdraw budget.  This route doesn't need bolts at all.  The crack in the corner hosts ample protection opportunities and wrist jams for rests (like you need to rest on a 35 foot climb).  I suppose this was given a 5.9 rating for the layaways on the arete before the anchors.  My guess is that this was intended to be a "face only" climb, whatever that is supposed to mean.  But I digress, this is good for a warm up and fun for the family to toprope.
content.location: Shady side of the canyon, three routes to the right of Run Bunny, Run.  Starts in a corner.  Walk off or rappel from the anchors.

content.description: Although the Goss guide gives this no stars, it has a few good moves and may serve as a good warm up for some of the harder routes down the line.  The crux starts right off the ground using a giant flake stuck in the ground to get started.  A few small crimps lead to great pockets. The only bummer is the ledge that breaks up the route.
content.location: Shares anchors with Run Bunny Run and New Age Disciples (middle route).

content.description: Amazing basalt climbing through very technical crimps pockets slopers and side pulls. Great crimper crux to chains!
content.location: Shady side on big obvious overhanging rock. Most aesthetic line on the cliff

content.description: Climb straight up and then make a difficult traverse left to gain the 2nd bolt (hard to clip, crux).  From here, go straight up aiming for positive holds on the black face above.  This route felt hard for the grade.   I assume a few key holds may have been damaged from the rockfall on the neighboring Ginsu.   Nice climb though!
content.location: Walk along the trail approximately 20 ft right of the start of Flying Off the Handle, 5.12b.  Start at the pile of rubble (note the bolt in one of the blocks on the ground, the block fell off of Ginsu, 5.11c).

content.description: Consistent 5.9 climbing up the 3 dimensional arete. Good holds, decent feet. A nice variety of moves.
content.location: Climbs the face of the arete.

content.description: F.Y.M. starts in a corner with a jagged boulder then trends left over a small bulge. The holds through the bulge crux are not as good as they look from below. A tricky leftward shuffle gets you to the final bolt. Pull onto the shelf and make a short move in order to clip the anchors.
content.protection: 4 bolts to a shared anchor with S.T.D.
content.location: Just right of S.T.D. Left of The Fellas, 5.9 on the arete.

content.description: This is located at the far left end of the shady side. I starts just right of a huge detached block and follows four bolts up to the anchors.  Thin crimps and balancy moves for a beginner.

One to remember...

Very much all of the grade, this heady little number will leave you feeling "heavy" at its crux.

Climb a stunning and sharp arete using pockets, breaks, and small, thin edges. Gain the crux at the mid-point, and battle your senses. Finish on seemingly easier terrain.
content.location:
This is currently the third to last route on the

Black Rock's Shady Side

west end.

content.description: Start out on the left side of the face. A lack of good right feet will push you a bit left at the start. Move back right soon as the climbing gets pretty straightforward. The grade eases off a bit as you near the top where there is a great clipping stance for the two bolt anchors.
content.protection: Five bolts for the climb, two for anchors.
content.location: A few feet left of Atlantis, 5.10B. These are the only two climbs on this small face.

content.description:
A steep and tense climb over big pockets and sharp edges. Short and stout, a subtle right leaning traverse across the face gains the anchors. A rather homogeneous

Black Rocks

route, but a good tick if you're in the area or want "one more for the road".
content.protection: Five bolts and a rap anchor.
content.location:
Located at the farthest west end of the

Shady Side

, this is currently the third to last route on the wall.

content.description:
A mild start leads to a steep, sequential, and thin crux. Touchy climbing past a few more bolts busts over a small lip to the anchors.

Nice edges and a series of big flakes are the lure of this climb.

Aesthetic and fun.
content.protection: Five bolts and a rap anchor.
content.location:
Located directly in the middle of the

Black Rock's Shady Side

,

The Beginning

sits isolated between

Atlantis

and

Your Problem

.

content.description: Recommended stick clip for bouldery direct start on thin positive holds (fun!). Pull onto the face and pad up the slab to a very square pocket/hole at the second bolt. Pocketed face climbing leads to the anchors.
content.protection: 4 bolts. Two bolt anchor with rap rings.
content.location: Bolted route on the same face as, but to the left of Entropy.

content.description: Climb the crumbly blocks to a blunt arete, and then onto the face. The crimpy and very technical crux is at the second bolt, but you can clip pretty easily before you try to pull the bulge on the sharp edges. It felt well protected.
content.location: farthest route on the right of the shady side area. (before you head over the little hill and down into the "shady side west" area.)
